body: following https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/issues/572 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/578)

comment_data.body: This is fine, I just want to note that it may cause compiler warnings on ILP64 systems (we have never tested any of those, so we have no idea if anything in toxcore works on them, anyway).

@iphydf  I have idea about how to detect if it's ILP64 or LP64(sizeof?). But i think it's fine since most computers are still using int of 4 bytes. And if it's ILP64, uint32_t is not large enough at all. In my view, we could sleep on it for now.

comment_regular_data.body:
[![CLA assistant check](https://cla-assistant.io/pull/badge/signed)](https://cla-assistant.io/TokTok/c-toxcore?pullRequest=578)
All committers have signed the CLA.
@xhebox You forget to update `toxav/toxav.c`
@Diablo oh my, sorry, i am so hurried
@xhebox: Can you rebase this on master and check the checkbox on the right to allow contributors to push to your PR branch? Also, the CI fails, likely because you didn't update toxav.api.h.

@iphydf sorry for the late reply, but there are still some controversial problems, that's why i stop working.. see https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/issues/572#issuecomment-331053303 , i am actually waiting for a reply about this comment, how do we deal with the '-1' flag? i've commented two options in the next comment, tell me if you have a better idea. i'm willing to continue my work if you give me a clear statement about it.

libvpx not specifying max bitrate and using integers that have implementation dependent widths complicates things a lot. No, this can't be. There **must** be max birate specified somewhere. Otherwise how is this even supposed to be portable? On one machine `unsigned int` might be 16 bits, on another 32-bit, yet on another 64 bits. Imagine a machine with 64-bit `unsinged int` sending video with `UINT64_MAX` bitrate to a machine with 32-bit `unsigned int`. It would just overflow. There must be a bitrate limit specified somewhere in VPX video stream protocol definition. Given that `unsigned int` is specified to  hold at least 16 bit integers, my guess would be that the max bitrate would be less or equal to that of `UINT16_MAX`, but guessing is bad, we should really find the actual bitrate specification rather than do the guessing.
@xhebox I see, thanks. I've replied on that issue.

@iphydf new commits pushed
@nurupo i've never thought so.👍
@xhebox code needs reformatting.

Well, my last comment is somewhat irrelevant to this PR or the issue in question in general, it was more of a reaction on zoff's comment in the issue thread https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/issues/572#issuecomment-357498359. Should have replied in there instead of here.
@xhebox run astyle on the code to format it, you can find astyle rule file and the command to use at https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/tree/master/other/astyle.

*[toxav/toxav.c, line 1052 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/578#-L2q0sOgfWOnISfoUQZB:-L2q0sOgfWOnISfoUQZC:bqxe6a7) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/32de659dd189ba0761a8ee9fa03b3b2206f8c4c3/toxav/toxav.c#L1052)):*
>because we also use uint

We use `uint32_t`, not `unsigned int`, these are different things, they can have different ranges.

I'd say that this function needs to return `bit_rate <= UINT_MAX`, to check if we would overflow `unsigned int` with our `uint32_t` value.

---

@iphydf new commit pushed
Thanks, waiting for @nurupo's review now, then I'll merge it.

As you can see, I've made branches in all the dependent repos to update to the new functions, and I found that the name doesn't flow very nicely. How about we do something like [this](https://github.com/iphydf/c-toxcore/commit/52fa7506450e2e5880227b646b9f3512830b2e95)? It uses apidsl properties, so it expresses the semantics a bit nicer, and makes it follow the naming standard.
@xhebox sorry about the back and forth. Since we're breaking the api, I'd prefer we get it right, so we break it as few times as possible

@iphydf It's ok, i appreciate your strict coding style :).

And yes, i thought about that. But i did not know what to do with that `event` at the time. It's kind of strange that i moved set() to audio,video space, but left bitrate_status() outside. Two separated callbacks are better on namespace and modularity, while one callback is convenient in most cases(two cbs will be a problem, as you dont know when and which callback is coming). I prefer the former, but the latter seems good, either. What do you think? As for moving set(), totally agreed.

Looks good to me. Get a LGTM from iphydf before merging though. --- Reviewed 1 of 4 files at r1, 3 of 3 files at r3. Set to 0 to disable > ``` Missing dot at the end. --- *[toxav/toxav.c, line 1052 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/578#-L2q0sOgfWOnISfoUQZB:-L3gMAKRIocOdpGY-K77:bkutd34) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/32de659dd189ba0761a8ee9fa03b3b2206f8c4c3/toxav/toxav.c#L1052)):*
Previously, nurupo wrote…
>because we also use uint We use `uint32_t`, not `unsigned int`, these are different things, they can have different ranges. I'd say that this function needs to return `bit_rate <= UINT_MAX`, to check if we would overflow `unsigned int` with our `uint32_t` value.
Right, I meant that the function needs to return `bit_rate > UINT_MAX`. Forgot that the function is called `invalid`, instead of `valid`. --- *[toxav/toxav.c, line 1056 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/578#-KsZJ-YuLlbrizh0KAYs-r2-1056:-L3gN67tP1GuXvBI43x0:b47d14f) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/e1e4fc34ff7300aa9550a59ec630039cb3450fb8/toxav/toxav.c#L1056)):*
Previously, xhebox wrote…
@iphydf I have idea about how to detect if it's ILP64 or LP64(sizeof?). But i think it's fine since most computers are still using int of 4 bytes. And if it's ILP64, uint32_t is not large enough at all. In my view, we could sleep on it for now.
@iphydf Why would this cause a warning and what would that warning be? --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/578#-:-L3gN_TbH-9TAAQCi3xY:bm75upx)*
Well, looks good apart from those missing ".".

@xhebox I think renaming the callback can be done in a separate PR. If I understand correctly, as long as there is video, the audio bit rate will never be reduced in the callback. Once there is no video, obviously only audio will be reduced. This means you'll never need to set the bit rate for both at the same time, so it makes sense to split the callback. Please double-check if I read the code correctly.

In this PR, fix @nurupo's comments and then I'll merge. Don't split the callbacks in this PR, because I'd like to get this merged soon, and it's green now :).

@iphydf here we go!
\o/ thanks! I'll squash all the commits and merge.
@iphydf can you keep the old ```toxav_bit_rate_set()``` as a wrapper that just calls the 2 new functions internally? no need to break api "just because we can".

commit.message:
Split bit_rate_set(), one for audio, one for video.

Fixes #572.

As discussed in the issue, there's a risk that toxcore may not hold the
maximum bitrates libvpx supports, if toxcore insists on using integer
type. I initially proposed to have another flag in set(), so that we can
use unsigned type instead. iphydf came up with a better solution, that is
splitting the original functions, one for audio, one for video. Now, we
could safely replace int32_t with uint32_t.

Also: clean video_bit_rate_invalid()

Though this is not a part of issue #572, as it's used in the
toxav_bit_rate_set(), i cleaned the code. As mannol said, there should be
a check. Uint32_t is large enough to hold the maximum bitrates libvpx
supports, but user may pass a value larger than uint while smaller than
uint32_t. Thanks to the reminding from nurupo, it's no longer a stub
function.

Bitrate error enums are shared for both audio and video
https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/pull/578#issuecomment-360095609, just
as iphydf said.

Split bit_rate_set(), one for audio, one for video.

Fixes #572.

As discussed in the issue, there's a risk that toxcore may not hold the
maximum bitrates libvpx supports, if toxcore insists on using integer
type. I initially proposed to have another flag in set(), so that we can
use unsigned type instead. iphydf came up with a better solution, that is
splitting the original functions, one for audio, one for video. Now, we
could safely replace int32_t with uint32_t.

Also: clean video_bit_rate_invalid()

Though this is not a part of issue #572, as it's used in the
toxav_bit_rate_set(), i cleaned the code. As mannol said, there should be
a check. Uint32_t is large enough to hold the maximum bitrates libvpx
supports, but user may pass a value larger than uint while smaller than
uint32_t. Thanks to the reminding from nurupo, it's no longer a stub
function.

Bitrate error enums are shared for both audio and video
https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/pull/578#issuecomment-360095609, just
as iphydf said.

labels.description: Refactoring production code, eg. renaming a variable, not affecting semantics
labels.name: refactor

title: Split toxav_bit_rate_set() into two functions to hold the maximum bitrates libvpx supports
